Being chattered at by Asian women trying to slyly lure you into their store for knock off handbags is weird. Once you get IN to Tribeca or Soho - it's fine but the walk down Canal is not my fave.The staff was very nice. The bed was comfortable. Although they didn't have a double as requested through Priceline so I had to bunk with my business associate (who was good sport)I've stayed in NY plenty of times and don't think I'll be back to this area or staying at this Sheraton again. Bucket list checked on that one..

I travel frequently to New York and try various hotels in the area. The Sheraton Tribeca is convenient for my travels so I thought I would give it a shot. The hotel appears to be relatively new, my first impression is it is quite tight on space, how they squeezed it in I don't know, you'll likely miss the front door (look for the Tribeca Bagel sign which is huge, and next door!). Inside however the reception, lobby, bar and casual computer area is very well done with high ceilings etc and it is very comfortable. The bar has good beers, cocktails etc and fun and friendly staff - to be honest all the staff were amazing, it's nice to have some banter and fun with them rather than they are just polite. There is also a starbucks on site, awesome :) There is a restaurant which I think is only open for breakfast so I didn't use it. All rooms you have to use a lift/elevator, there are 3 so you can have a little wait. The corridors to the rooms are tight, not a big deal but gives you a sense that they squeezed this in. The room itself was as expected, very new and clean which is always a good start, the bed/linen was great. There is a desk for working, but with cases etc space was a bit of a premium. I had room service, must say the food was very good, but again tight space on where to sit/eat. The room overlooked the road, and traffic noise was an issue (I was on floor 9), just a warning, this is New York, it is a big city and the hotel is on a main street. The internet was also wanting, "speed" was an issue and drop outs using WiFi, however when I used the ethernet cable things were fine (I'm a technology guy, it wasn't a "user" issue!). The Sheraton also have this Green initiative going, where you don't get new towels/linen everyday, which is a good thing but be warned this means you're off the housekeeping list, so you need to call down for bins and they don't tidy the room/make the bed etc.Overall the room was a little tight, but well kept, the traffic noise and internet was an issue (but the Lenovo's in the lobby were great). I'd really like to give this 3.5 stars, I think 3 is probably a little too low but not quite 4 stars either. The bar, staff etc are all brilliant and the location is great too. There are plenty of other options in the area in the same price range, I'm sure they have their pro's and con's too (I've stayed in many!). It's not a bad choice by any stretch, but has a lot of competition that you could consider in the same price range.

Decent breakfast, nice bed and good location. **Most important thing is don't book a club room for the view - it is not guaranteed. I booked it based on website and I was facing a wall. Only book it if you want a high floor with breakfast and free internet, otherwise get a regular room.I was VERY upset when I saw my view but corporate customer service and the general manager handled the issue well - I commend them for their customer service. The rest of the hotel staff was not as helpful with regards to the view issue.

You don't go to New York to spend your time at the hotel, which is why this property is an excellent choice. Nothing fancy, very standard lobby & rooms. You get everything you need. As far as location; walking distance to Soho, chinatown & little italy. There's 2 very convenient subway stations to help get you through the city. We were in midtown in 5-6 minutes & even made it to Brooklyn in about 10 minutes!
user_name:
Jenmar89
New York City, New York

review_body: A very practical place. Relatively cheap. Clean. Excellent service. My next-door neighbors were very noisy late at night: I phoned the reception and the issue was resolved quickly and efficiently.I'm used to staying in the Upper-East Side or Midtown hotels. I had this (apparently privately owned) Sheraton booked for me by mistake (instead of the Midtown one)... But didn't regret it one bit: It's much cheaper that it's where-it's-at competition. But it's not the main point. The main point is the quality (and the price) of food in the area. In the Upper East Side etc., the food is lousy and/or very expensive. But in Tribeca one has an excellent choice of all kinds of excellent restaurants at very reasonable prices. In fact, right around the corner from that Sheraton there is a superb Japanese restaurant (I'll review it... in Italian... :))) that would've been prohibitively expensive only 6 miles up north. So, this hotel is not fancy but a decent place to stay at. Lots of youth stay there.

Room was recently renovated and felt upscale and trendy (as was the lobby). Bed was comfortable and room, though small, was not terribly noisy (saying a lot for NYC hotels). Staff were very friendly. Located right next to subway and many restaurants. Great rate from Hotel Tonight app. Would stay again..
user_name:
DCguy20002
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The hotel was great. Location could not be better if you like to visit Soho, China Town, Lower Manhattan and anything else down there. very close to the N and R line for travel uptown. My one piece of advice is to get a room that does not face the post office. You can hear the trucks backing up. Nicholas at the front desk was great. Picked out the perfect room. All in all a great stay.
